Tickets for Musical Club
Events Go On Sale
Today In Levering
Tickets for the annual home concert and dance sponsored by the
Musical Club will go on sale today
in Levering Hall, it was said by
Ronald Levy, president of the organization. The affair will take
place next Friday, March 4.
Tickets for the concert alone will
be sold at $1.50, or one may be
gotten with a Students Activities
card free of ~arge. Tickets to
the dance to foiTow will cost $1.00
per couple. Osmar Steinwald and
his Eleven Clubmen will provide the
music.

Election of new officers, short
talks, and reports on progress
made will feature t'he meeting of
the graduate Varsity Club in Levering Hall at 8 P. M. today, Eben
F. Perkins, incumbent secretarytreasurer said yesterday.
Dempster To Talk
At the business meeting tonight, which is to be attended by
ma_n y undergraduate and graduate members of the organization, in addition to those connected with athletics at Hopkins,
R. N. Dempster, registrar, will
in a talk on "Status of Hopkins
Undergraduate Work" discuss,
among other things, curriculum
revisions and increase in enrollment at Homewood.
Robert Roy, who played wing
defense for the 1928 Jay twelve
which was sent to Amsterdam to
represent Hopkins in the Olympics, is expected to briefly discuss
the Johns Hoo kins Varsity La'v- ----a"Osfe' ci~_ili:£~rmerly called the
Olympics. Henry Iddins, business
manager of athletics here, will
explain the Olympic lacrosse playoff system for the selection of a
representative U. S. team.
Elections To Be Held
Following the reading of a report on the past two years' work
of the Varsity Club, said Mr.
Perkins, elections will be held
tonight for new officers, an executive committee composed of 12
men, and three delegates to the
Athletic Association Council. The
total number of delegates, it was
explained, is four, the fourth delegate being the president of the
graduate Varsity Club.

The organization, having on its
roll all Hopkins graduates who
won major letters in athletics, is
at present headed by Karl w.
Schmidt.
Gives Scholarships
The club gives annually a limited number of scholarships which
are in the nature of Honor
Awards based upon the general
plan of the Rhodes Scholarships.
Scholastic ability, character, and
physical vigor are taken into account when applications are considered.

"Minnie the Moocher," that torrid fox-trot of casino jazz kings,
caused three chaperons at a recent
dance at Barnard College to remove their glasses and wipe them
carefully. Then they looked. The
number resulted in "impropriety"
on the part of the terpsichoreans,
according to the chaperons. The
girls, it seems, leaned their heads
too, too near those of their escorts;
and their escorts appeared all too,
too willing to respond by the "close
in" whatever that may be.

When you walk through an art
gallery. and look up at the marble
statues of Miltiades, Pericles and
other famous Greeks, you are not
always seeing the features of the
great men as they appeared in life.
In fact, if a citizen of ancient
Athens were to join you in the tour
of the gallery, he probably could
not identify \;-ery many of his national heroes from the sculptor's
portraits.
Greek artists did not ordinarily
try to reproduce the exact features
o£ human beings before the fourth
century B. C., when the Golden
Age of Greece was at its height,
declares Dr. Elmer G. Suhr, who
had conducted research at the
Johns Hopkins University on the
sculptured portraits of Greek

statesmen. Dr. Suhr has just published his results in a volume
issued by the Johns Hopkins Press.
Reason In Religion
The main reason why the sculptors of Greece did not turn their
skill to preserving the features of
their great men is traced to their
religion. Sculptors gave their best
efforts to statues of Apollo, Athena
and other deities. They tried to
make the figures as beautifully perfeet as the gods were thought to be.
For centuries the Greek sculptor
was bound by the tradition that a
human being's statue could not
stand on a level with that of a god:
And when the sculptor Phidias,
who lived in the fifth century, dared
to place his features on the shield

Started In Economics Seminary
Dr. Teper had his start on this
monograph while a member of the
Economic Seminary at the Hopkins. Materials contained in the
files of the Office of the Commissioner of Labor and Statistics of
Maryland, publications of that office, of the U. S. Bureau of Labor
Statistics, and of the North CaroJina Department of Labor and
Printing, as well as of other government agencies were utilized as
sources of informati-on.
The subject discussed is divided
into two parts: "Hours of Labor in
Relation to Various Factors" which
contains two chapters "Data and
Method" and "Relations Between
Hours of Labor and Other Factors;" and "The Movement of the
Hours of Labor in the United
States from 1890 to 1928." This
topic has three sub-topics which
deal with the "Method and Scope"
of this movement, the "Movement
of Hours of Labor" and "The Reduction in Working Rours."
Preface Expresses Thanks
In the preface of the monograph
the author expresses his indebtedness to Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, Dr.
G. E. Barnett and Dr. G. H. Evans
for "stimulating the production of
his work and for assistance received
at every stage of his inquiry." The
Lessing Rosenthal Fund gave financial aid in the publishing of the
work.

DR. W. F. ALBRIGHT IS TO
SPEAK ON BETH-ZUR WORKS
AT ASSEMBLY NEXT THURS.
Professor Of Semetic Languages
At Hopkins Was Adviser On
Expedition Last Year
Dr. W. F. Albright, professor of
semetic languages at the Hopkins,
is scheduled to speak at the weekly
assembly next Thursday morning
on his excavations at Beth-Zur last
June:
Excavated In June-July
The excavations about which Dr.
Albright is to speak were conducted
in Palestine from June 1 to July 29
under the joint auspices of the
American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem and the Presbyterian Theological Seminary of
Chicago. Dr. 0. R. Sellers, who
received his Ph. D. at the Hopkins
in 1921, represented the latter.
The Hellenistic areas of the city
yielded, in the work done, streets,
houses, a small inn, a large reservoir outside the south wall, and
many plastered installations of
enigmatic character. Among the
small objects dug up are seals and
gems and bronze articles of every
description.
Was Archaeological Adviser
Dr. Albright was the archeaeological adviser on the expedition in
which there were six other Americans and seven Egyptian surveyors.

Activities for the 1932 lacrosse
season at the J olms Hopkins swing
under way as tomorrow at 2 P. M.
at I--l omewood Field more than 60
a re expected to be greeted by Coach
Ray Van Orman and his assistants
who are to organize regular practice.
Fifteen Vets Back
\i\Tith fifteen veteran first-string
players from the 1931 squad, which
was rated third best lacrosse twelve
in the country, the Jays, with a
well-balanced schedule, have turned
their eyes on the great competition
for the right to represent the
United States against foreign teams
in the Olympics at Los Angeles in
the summer.
Darrell, Beehler,
Weitzel, Ness, Bernard, Turnbull,
Stude, Kneip, Tripless, Lang and
Levy will be available for the 1932
campaign. Among the new men
who are expected to report tomorrow there may be some excelle~~ m~te~ial fo~ reserv_e stre~
which, it 1s expected, w11f bebuilt
up this season.
Despite the fact that a majority
of last year's squad will be playing
again this season, Coach Van Orman expects no easy season. The
power of Princeton, Army, and
Maryland, especially, is recognized
by the lacrosse coaching - staff at
Homewood. These three college
twelves are regarded as a possible
"menace" to the powerful Jay team.
Attack Brilliant
The brilliance and speed of the
Hopkins attack has come in for
much commendation, even from
Coach Dinty Moore, St. John's lacrosse mentor. Using swift, accurate passes the Jays dazzled many
of their opponents last season as
Turnbull, Beehler, Darrell, and
Don Kelly starred on the fast
offense.
State college teams are all anxious to play in the Olympics.
St. J ohn's 1 three-time national
champion and representative of this
country against the Canadian AllS tars in the international series
here last spring, was heavily hit by
graduation. \i\Then first practice was
held two weeks ago at Annapolis
only seven veterans were available:
Lotz, Morris, Carpenter, defense;
Ziegler, Lynch, Athey, and Trader,
attack. They will form the nucleus
of the Johnnie team, which may yet
meet the Jays this season.
Maryland Has Vet Squad
Maryland, which spilled the
Homewood lacrossemen on a wet
field last year, will be a formidable
foe in the fight for the right to
play for: the U. S. in the Olympic
games. With the return of a veteran
squad, the College Parkers will be
a tough twelve to beat.
Another major Maryland state
contender, which does not meet the
Jays, is Navy which was hard hit
by graduation. However, eight
veterans remain for the 1932 campaign. James, Moncure, Smith,
Elliott, Diel, "Reedy, West, and
Ferguson will be available to Coach
George Finlayson.

THE TIME DRAWS NEAR

Lacrosse at Hopkins always has
been the favorite sport ~f many of
~d~r1Yraduates and alumni and
the old "r°ndian game" was start~d
at the University many years ago.
The teams put out by the Black and
Blue always rate among the best in
the country and this year's should
fulfill the fondest expectations of
its supporters.
With the Olympic games just in
the offing and the know ledge that
some lacrosse team will carry the
American colors against England
and Canada in California in the
coming month of August, interest
in the possibilities of the Jays being
the chosen twelve have already
reached a high degree.
Far! be it from us to attempt to
predict what the outcome finally
will be or what team will go to
California this summer-however
we will say that the Jays have as
good a chance to be there as any
other group has. They have a
wealth of experienced mat'erial left
from last year's team, which will be
boulstered up by the new lacrosse
stars who entered last fall from the
several high schools. Considering
this fact and also taking into account the fact that some of the
stronger teams of last year, will be
in a weakened condition due to the
loss of some of their last year's
regulars by graduation, we feel that
Hopkins' chances are even more
enhanced.
But every member of the Jay
lacrosse team, from the last and
lowliest sub to the mightiest star,
must remember that the goal is not
to be reached until every opponent
has been met and successfully
dealt with. Any case of swell headedness by any member of the squad,
no matter who he might be, will
greatly minimize the chances of the
team to be selected for repr.~senta­
tion. Therefore every lacrosse man
should take his job seriously and
perform his task as proficiently as
he is able.

WRESTLI NG IS IN ITS
1NFANCY

GENEVA, Switzerland - "An
International Enquiry into the Costs
of Living" is the title of the 210page report issued last month by /the
International Labor Office in Geneva, the so-called Ford wage report.
This is the study made in answer to
the question, "V/ha't wage should
workers get in each of the Ford
European factories to let them live
at a standard equivalent to that of
a $7-a-day man in Detroit?"
When this question was raised
early in 1929 by the head of the
of the Ford Motor Company in
Europe, the Labor Off:ce undertook to re:ply·, with the help--Gf---a$25,000 fund furnished by Edward
A. Filene of Boston, and a twoyear study, culminating in the report described above, was the result.
The volume is a mass of statistics,
from which one must dig out conclusions. It appears, however, that
a wage lower than that of Detroit
would permit the Detroit standard
of living in all the fourteen cities
investigated, except Stockholm,
where it would need to be about
4 per cent higher. In the other
thirteen cities a wage equivalent to
the Detroit standard would range
from as much as 42 per cent lower
in Barcelona to 7 per cent lower in
Frankfort. Or expressed somewhat
differently, the Ford standard could
be duplicated in Cork, for example,
for 85 per cent what it costs in
Detroit, in Warsaw for 67 per cent,
and in Istanbul for 65 per cent.
The study had to begin, of course,
in Detroit where the United States
Bureau of Labor statistics made a
careful canvass to determine exactly what the Ford wages mean in
terms of food, clothing, housing,
etc. Then with the Detroit average budget in hand, the cost of a
similar standard was determined in
each of the fourteen Europf:'.an
cities. Unfortunately the report
does not give any data showing how
its figures compare with wages being paid. Employer members of the
Govering Body of the I. L. O. were
afraid of such comparisons and
prevented their being made. Other
data, however, provided by the Institute of Scientific Management in
Geneva, show that actual . wages
paid machinists are everywhere below the Detroit Standard.

"On the basis of the excellent
draft treaty provided for the conference after years of careful preparation, it is possible that technical
limitation or reduction may be
achieved. Too much hope should
be avoided, however, for false
optimism is dangerous. The solution of European problems is confronting the conference before that
of the Manchurian crisis, and rests
both upon the ability of France and
Germany to agree concerning Central Europe and armament status,
and upon the willingness of the
United States to cooperate fully in
the settlement of the complex issues
involved.
"This is literally a race with
death. The sole source of optimism
rests in the fact that the statesman
of every country are actually con£erring in a desperate attempt to
solve the disagreements threatening the downfall of civilization. The
solution of the present anarchy can
only be reached by the gradual delegation of sovereignty to a central
government with authority to effect
the pacific settlement of disputes. I
believe it is to American interest
to lead the way in this direction.
Financial entanglements across the
Atlantic -and the Pacific have so
thoroughly destroyed our political
isolation that only a reversal of our
attitude and policy can save our
own as well as the world economic
structure.
College Students Face Annihilation

"It is constantly urged here that
college students be made to realize
immediately that in case of failure
they face annihilation within thirty
years. Participation in political life
with a constant demand for constructive domestic and foreign policies is essential if the present generation is not to be swept into
another catastrophe. Colleges alone
supply the intellectual and moral
leadership sufficient to rescue humanity.
Liberal Clubs, International Relations Groups, and
Christian Associations must assume
responsibility for such endeavor."

Princeton, College Of Riots

Princeton is the college of riots.
There has been a series of them
from 1800 to 1930. Lengths of
prayers, poor food and unpopular
presidents have been the causes
for some/of them. The worst upheaval occurred in 1817 when the
tutors were locked in their rooms
and attacked with bricks and
wooden bats.

Miss Janet Hegner At Rome
University On Fellowship
For 1931-32
Two students from the Johns
Hopkins Lniversity are doing interesting and valuable work
abroad, according to Dr. Kent R.
Greenfield, professor of modern
European history , in whose department they are \Yorking.
Mr. John Lutz, a graduate of
St. John's, has been in Paris since
September searching for the unpublished letters of Louis Blanc.
He is attempting to lay the foundation for a future biography of
Louis Blanc, of whom none has
been written. Mr. Lutz is conducting his researches -. at the
Bibliotheque Nationale and the
Archives Nationale.
Although he is getting results
at present and intends staying
another year, according to Dr.
Greenfield, Mr. Lutz was rather
disheartened at about Christmas
time. He wrote then to the Hopkins professor expressing the
hope that "Santa Claus would be
kind enough to supply the Bibliotheque Nationale with a new card
case, in place of the tedious present one."
---~--~M_i_ss Janet Hegner, a graduate
of Raclclyffe~Who·h~s taken
courses at the Hopkins, is at present at Rome University, on an exchange fellowship from the Institute of International Education.
The fellowship is for this year
only. Miss Hegner is interested
in a prelimnary study of the activities of the Papal government,
especially in connection with
their change from the mediaeval
attitude. This particular field is
of great interest to Dr. Greenfield, who is in touch with the
activities of Miss Hegner, as well
as those of Mr. Lutz.

When you walk through an art
gallery. and look up at the marble
statues of Miltiades, Pericles and
other famous Greeks, you are not
always seeing the features of the
great men as they appeared in life.
In fact, if a citizen of ancient
Athens were to join you in the tour
of the gallery, he probably could
not identify \;-ery many of his national heroes from the sculptor's
portraits.
Greek artists did not ordinarily
try to reproduce the exact features
o£ human beings before the fourth
century B. C., when the Golden
Age of Greece was at its height,
declares Dr. Elmer G. Suhr, who
had conducted research at the
Johns Hopkins University on the
sculptured portraits of Greek

Reason In Religion
The main reason why the sculptors of Greece did not turn their
skill to preserving the features of
their great men is traced to their
religion. Sculptors gave their best
efforts to statues of Apollo, Athena
and other deities. They tried to
make the figures as beautifully perfeet as the gods were thought to be.
For centuries the Greek sculptor
was bound by the tradition that a
human being's statue could not
stand on a level with that of a god:
And when the sculptor Phidias,
who lived in the fifth century, dared
to place his features on the shield

Dr. Teper had his start on this
monograph while a member of the
Economic Seminary at the Hopkins. Materials contained in the
files of the Office of the Commissioner of Labor and Statistics of
Maryland, publications of that office, of the U. S. Bureau of Labor
Statistics, and of the North CaroJina Department of Labor and
Printing, as well as of other government agencies were utilized as
sources of informati-on.
The subject discussed is divided
into two parts: "Hours of Labor in
Relation to Various Factors" which
contains two chapters "Data and
Method" and "Relations Between
Hours of Labor and Other Factors;" and "The Movement of the
Hours of Labor in the United
States from 1890 to 1928." This
topic has three sub-topics which
deal with the "Method and Scope"
of this movement, the "Movement
of Hours of Labor" and "The Reduction in Working Rours."

Excavated In June-July
The excavations about which Dr.
Albright is to speak were conducted
in Palestine from June 1 to July 29
under the joint auspices of the
American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem and the Presbyterian Theological Seminary of
Chicago. Dr. 0. R. Sellers, who
received his Ph. D. at the Hopkins
in 1921, represented the latter.
The Hellenistic areas of the city
yielded, in the work done, streets,
houses, a small inn, a large reservoir outside the south wall, and
many plastered installations of
enigmatic character. Among the
small objects dug up are seals and
gems and bronze articles of every
description.
Was Archaeological Adviser

which there were six other Americans and seven Egyptian surveyors.

THE TIME DRAWS NEAR

Lacrosse at Hopkins always has
been the favorite sport ~f many of
~d~r1Yraduates and alumni and
the old "r°ndian game" was start~d
at the University many years ago.
The teams put out by the Black and
Blue always rate among the best in
the country and this year's should
fulfill the fondest expectations of
its supporters.
With the Olympic games just in
the offing and the know ledge that
some lacrosse team will carry the
American colors against England
and Canada in California in the
coming month of August, interest
in the possibilities of the Jays being
the chosen twelve have already
reached a high degree.
Far! be it from us to attempt to
predict what the outcome finally
will be or what team will go to
California this summer-however
we will say that the Jays have as
good a chance to be there as any
other group has. They have a
wealth of experienced mat'erial left
from last year's team, which will be
boulstered up by the new lacrosse
stars who entered last fall from the
several high schools. Considering
this fact and also taking into account the fact that some of the
stronger teams of last year, will be
in a weakened condition due to the
loss of some of their last year's
regulars by graduation, we feel that
Hopkins' chances are even more
enhanced.
But every member of the Jay
lacrosse team, from the last and
lowliest sub to the mightiest star,
must remember that the goal is not
to be reached until every opponent
has been met and successfully
dealt with. Any case of swell headedness by any member of the squad,
no matter who he might be, will
greatly minimize the chances of the
team to be selected for repr.~senta­
tion. Therefore every lacrosse man
should take his job seriously and
perform his task as proficiently as
he is able.

1NFANCY

GENEVA, Switzerland - "An
International Enquiry into the Costs
of Living" is the title of the 210page report issued last month by /the
International Labor Office in Geneva, the so-called Ford wage report.
This is the study made in answer to
the question, "V/ha't wage should
workers get in each of the Ford
European factories to let them live
at a standard equivalent to that of
a $7-a-day man in Detroit?"
When this question was raised
early in 1929 by the head of the
of the Ford Motor Company in
Europe, the Labor Off:ce undertook to re:ply·, with the help--Gf---a$25,000 fund furnished by Edward
A. Filene of Boston, and a twoyear study, culminating in the report described above, was the result.
The volume is a mass of statistics,
from which one must dig out conclusions. It appears, however, that
a wage lower than that of Detroit
would permit the Detroit standard
of living in all the fourteen cities
investigated, except Stockholm,
where it would need to be about
4 per cent higher. In the other
thirteen cities a wage equivalent to
the Detroit standard would range
from as much as 42 per cent lower
in Barcelona to 7 per cent lower in
Frankfort. Or expressed somewhat
differently, the Ford standard could
be duplicated in Cork, for example,
for 85 per cent what it costs in
Detroit, in Warsaw for 67 per cent,
and in Istanbul for 65 per cent.
The study had to begin, of course,
in Detroit where the United States
Bureau of Labor statistics made a
careful canvass to determine exactly what the Ford wages mean in
terms of food, clothing, housing,
etc. Then with the Detroit average budget in hand, the cost of a
similar standard was determined in
each of the fourteen Europf:'.an
cities. Unfortunately the report
does not give any data showing how
its figures compare with wages being paid. Employer members of the
Govering Body of the I. L. O. were
afraid of such comparisons and
prevented their being made. Other
data, however, provided by the Institute of Scientific Management in
Geneva, show that actual . wages
paid machinists are everywhere below the Detroit Standard.

"On the basis of the excellent
draft treaty provided for the conference after years of careful preparation, it is possible that technical
limitation or reduction may be
achieved. Too much hope should
be avoided, however, for false
optimism is dangerous. The solution of European problems is confronting the conference before that
of the Manchurian crisis, and rests
both upon the ability of France and
Germany to agree concerning Central Europe and armament status,
and upon the willingness of the
United States to cooperate fully in
the settlement of the complex issues
involved.
"This is literally a race with
death. The sole source of optimism
rests in the fact that the statesman
of every country are actually con£erring in a desperate attempt to
solve the disagreements threatening the downfall of civilization. The
solution of the present anarchy can
only be reached by the gradual delegation of sovereignty to a central
government with authority to effect
the pacific settlement of disputes. I
believe it is to American interest
to lead the way in this direction.
Financial entanglements across the
Atlantic -and the Pacific have so
thoroughly destroyed our political
isolation that only a reversal of our
attitude and policy can save our
own as well as the world economic
structure.
College Students Face Annihilation

"It is constantly urged here that
college students be made to realize
immediately that in case of failure
they face annihilation within thirty
years. Participation in political life
with a constant demand for constructive domestic and foreign policies is essential if the present generation is not to be swept into
another catastrophe. Colleges alone
supply the intellectual and moral
leadership sufficient to rescue humanity.
Liberal Clubs, International Relations Groups, and
Christian Associations must assume
responsibility for such endeavor."

Princeton, College Of Riots

Princeton is the college of riots.
There has been a series of them
from 1800 to 1930. Lengths of
prayers, poor food and unpopular
presidents have been the causes
for some/of them. The worst upheaval occurred in 1817 when the
tutors were locked in their rooms
and attacked with bricks and
wooden bats.

Miss Janet Hegner At Rome
University On Fellowship
For 1931-32
Two students from the Johns
Hopkins Lniversity are doing interesting and valuable work
abroad, according to Dr. Kent R.
Greenfield, professor of modern
European history , in whose department they are \Yorking.
Mr. John Lutz, a graduate of
St. John's, has been in Paris since
September searching for the unpublished letters of Louis Blanc.
He is attempting to lay the foundation for a future biography of
Louis Blanc, of whom none has
been written. Mr. Lutz is conducting his researches -. at the
Bibliotheque Nationale and the
Archives Nationale.
Although he is getting results
at present and intends staying
another year, according to Dr.
Greenfield, Mr. Lutz was rather
disheartened at about Christmas
time. He wrote then to the Hopkins professor expressing the
hope that "Santa Claus would be
kind enough to supply the Bibliotheque Nationale with a new card
case, in place of the tedious present one."
---~--~M_i_ss Janet Hegner, a graduate
of Raclclyffe~Who·h~s taken
courses at the Hopkins, is at present at Rome University, on an exchange fellowship from the Institute of International Education.
The fellowship is for this year
only. Miss Hegner is interested
in a prelimnary study of the activities of the Papal government,
especially in connection with
their change from the mediaeval
attitude. This particular field is
of great interest to Dr. Greenfield, who is in touch with the
activities of Miss Hegner, as well
as those of Mr. Lutz.
